note.p: One of three imprint variants of this edition; this is probably the first (see "The Library" 10 (Dec. 1988), p. 317-38).
Reproduction of the original in the Bodleian Library.

div.p: THE DVKES MISTRIS, As IT WAS PRESENted by her Majesties Servants, At the private House in Drury-Lane.
LONDON, Printed by JOHN NORTON, for ANDREW CROOKE and WILLIAM COOKE. 1638. 6

lg.l: SO various are the pallates of our Age
That nothing is presented on the Stage,
Though nere so square, and apted to the Lawes
Of poesy, that can winne full applause,
This likes a story, that a cunning plot
This wit, that lines, here one, he know's not what.
But after all this looking severall wayes,
We do obserue the generall guests to Playes,
Meet in opinion of two straines: that please
Satire, and wantonnes, the last of these
Though old, if in new dressing it appeare
Will move a smile from all, but shall not heare.
Our Author hath no guilt of scurrile friends.
For Satire they do know best what it meanes,
That dare apply, and if a Poets Pen,
Ayming at generall errors not the men,
'Tis not his fault, the safest cure is, they
That purge their bosomes, may see any Play.
But here we quit your feare of Satire too,
And with these disadvantages to you
Thus humbly bow, to such helpes tane away
What hope is there many will like the Play,
But good or bad, have patience but two howers,
The Poets credit is at stake with ours.

div.head: Actus Primus.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: WEe are like to have a brave, and jolly time on't.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: The Court looks now as't should be, after such
A tempest, what should follow but a calme,
And Sun-beames? wher's the Dutchesse?
And yet as the case stands, we can scarce give her
That title, all her glory is eclips'd,
Shee's i'th west, poore gentle-woman I can
But pity her, I meane Euphemia.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I dare not speake.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou mayst speake any thing
That's Courtly, and in fashion.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But the Duke.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Is Duke, and Heaven preserve him, let him have
His humor, and his Mistresses, what are we
The worse, nay lets consider like wise-men
We are the better for't, it gives us liberty,
And matter for our dutifull imitation.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But she was his Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: A Lady of,
A flowing sweetnes, and but in his eyes
Can want no beauty, how her nature may
Thus cruelly affronted, keepe that soft,
And noble temper.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Take heede, and be wise,
We are or should be Courtiers, if it please
The Duke for reasons best knowne to himselfe
To have more Wives, I say 'tis fit he have 'em,
I make it my owne ease.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Thou art not married.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, I dare not for that reason, cause I hold it
Unfit my conscience should be limited,
But we are private men, and though the Lawes
Have power on us, the State, and Dukedome may
Suffer, if he that is the soule of all,
I meane the Duke, should wast his life with one,
One melancholy wife, come let me tell thee
Since he has chosen one, that he thinks fayrer
'Tis happy for his first to keepe her head on,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Coulst thou have thought so cruell, las Euphemia

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No thou art deceiv'd, if I were Duke
'Tis ten to one I'de have noe Wife at all,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not of mine owne, while any of my subjects
Had those I could affect; whom I wo'd have
Presented by their husbands, they should doe
Themselves that curtesie, none would denie,
Considering what may follow.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Besides Hornes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Right, if the toy be gamesome, the husbands made
For ever.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And his Wife a great one,
Hornes excuse for all.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The old mind still.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know my constitution
His countenance weares some sore of discontent
Do'es he not appeare Cloudy.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Lett's speake to him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord,— my Lord.
Not answer.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: He does not heare.
My noblest Lord.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If I did thinke he were proud now of a suddaine,
I wod not aske him how he do'es, to save
His life— I'le speake once more, my worthiest Lord,
Leontio.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ha waken'd him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Valerio, and Siluio.
I am your servants.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not that we grudge our duties to your Lordship
Or breath, for without flattery, I dare
Be hoarse with praysing, and with praying for you,
But we would willingly have your Lordship take
Notice, when we expresse our hearts to serve you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your pardon gentlemen, I am confident
You have more vertue then to let me suffer in your opinions

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You looke sad.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And talke as you had but started from a dreame,
I dare not be too bold to enquire the cause,
But your face will teach others melancholie.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Now in this generall mirth it must appeare,
The greater wonder to behold your trouble.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I shall betray my selfe, keepe in my passions.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ther's something in't more then we apprehend.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What should distract the freedome of your sole
Kinsman, and onely favourite to the Duke,
The peoples love too, and these seldome meete,
The minion of the Souldiers, who honour you
Most infinitly for your valour, and your bounty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Flatter not gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le be your hinde first.
Ecclipse not, Sr, the glories of your minde
with this strange melancholy, I wod not for
My hopes the Duke should see this dulnes, he
May with unhappy jealousie interpret—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What Jealousie?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is my heart transparent?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now ioy revels in the Court,
By his command, and his example too;
Doe not affront his pleasure, I am bold,
But 'tis my zeale, that wo'd not have you suffer,
And you may give it pardon.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I must thanke
Thy love Valerio, thy heart does speake
A noble friendship, you shall witnesse Gentlemen
I will be very pleasant, keepe, keepe in
Yee rebell thoughts, and take some other time
To shew your wildnes.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Observ'd you that?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Shall I be bold to aske your Lordship a que-stion?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: You will pardon the folly on't?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What is't? be cleare with me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are you not in love, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: In Love?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have shrewd coniectures.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: From what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: From these dull Symptomes, if you be

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Let me be your Physition, 'tis a woman
I must presume.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What does a man love else?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: There be those men are in love with their own cloathes
Their wits, their follies, their estates, themselves,
But if you love a woman, let me advise you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Heare him my Lord, his practise upon that sex
Has made him learn'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Something I have observ'd
After a hundred Mistresses, I had beene dull else,
But to the point.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How would you advise mee?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I would not counsell you not to love at all,
As some that are all Satyr, 'gainst the sex,
Love me a hansome Lady, but so love her
That still your heart finde roome for a fresh beautie,
For twentie, for a thousand.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is inconstancie
So easie, and so pardonable.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Whydee' shift
Your shirt, the linnen's fine, but not so cleane
And sweete after a Journey, 'tis a Justice
To change: and a security a woman
Is Tyrant, when she finds a dotage, Love
But wisely, to delight our hearts, not ruine 'em
With too severe impression.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Prethee tell me,
What doe most men desire that are in love?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In this wise love I meane? why, my Lord, they
Desire to enioy their Mistresses, what else
Can be expected? and 'tis necessary
In my opinion.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hadst thou beene woman,
Thou wod'st not have beene so cruell.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, my Lord,
I know not how the sex might have corrupted mee
But had I beene Adonis, without question
My Lady Venus should have had no cause
To accuse my bashfullnesse, I should have left
The Forrest to have hunted—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But I must be content.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nothing will much trouble thy head Ualerio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I doe not vex my selfe with much inquirie
What men doe in the Indies, or what Trade
The great Turke's on, nor what his designe is,
Nor does the State at home much trouble me,
After the warres I enioy my limbs, and can
Boast some activitie, untill some woman
In kindnesse take me downe, be ruled by me,
Employ your spring and youth upon those Joyes
They are fit for, beget a new Elizium,
Under some pleasing shade lets lie and laugh
Our Temples crown'd with Roses, with the choyse,
And richest blood of Grapes, quicken our veines,
Some faire cheek'd boyes skinking our swelling Cups,
And we with Joviall soules shooting them round
At each mans lip a Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I did looke for this before.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They in this Bower
Shall with their Songs, and Musicke charme our eares,
And nimbly dance, their bright haire loosely spread;
Nor shall they more their amorous beauties hide
Then those contended for the golden Ball.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou wod'st imagine many fine devices
But after all these pleasures, as there is
A limit, and a period set, what will
Succeed these raptures, when they are past enjoyings
But leave so many stings upon our thoughts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We wo'not thinke of that, or if we do,
Wee'le venture upon Fortunes curtesie.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou art resolute Valerio, if ere sorrow
Lay seige to me, i'le wish thee my companion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am your humble creature, and shall be honord
In your commands.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: My Lord, the Duke
Ask'd for you.
sp.stage: Ascanio whispers with Valerio, and Silvio. Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I'le attend. Whither in hast?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We are commanded to attend

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It is his pleasure, we should waite upon her
To his presence.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ardelia,
It will become you, and but that his highnes
Exacts my person, I should be a part
Of her attendance, but not serve her with
Halfe the devotion, I would pay Euphemia
The too much injur'd Dutchesse, now a stranger
To the Dukes bosome, while another sits,
And rules his heart, but this prepares my happines,
My hopes grow from her misery, which may
Encline Euphemia to pity me.
I must use art.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good Madam have more comfort.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is not that she? her habite like her Fortune
Most blacke, and ominous, heer's a change of State,
Noe noyse of waiters, and officious troopes,
Of Courtiers futter here, where are the traine
Of Ladies, with more blossome then the Spring,
Ambitious to present their duties to her,
Where be those Jewells, whose proud blaze did use
To vye with Sun-beames, and strike gazers blind?
All gone behind a Cloud? how she observes
The Structures, which more soft then Dionisio
seeme to incline their marble heads, and sweate
In the compassion of her iniury,
My heart is labouring for breath, and yet
I dare not speake to her, the Duke has spies
Upon her; and his anger carries ruine.

div.stage: Enter Courtiers, who passe by neglectfully.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Sure I should know this place.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Tis the Court Madam.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: And those were Courtiers that past by?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They were.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Some of them serv'd me once, but now the Duke
Has discharg'd all, why dost not thou forsake me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I serv'd you Madam, for your selfe, and cannot
Thinke on you with lesse reverence, for your change:
Of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Is not that Leontio?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It is Madam.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Does he decline me too? though I am miserable,
My griefe wo'd not infect him, but he must
Compose himselfe to please, the Duke, whose creature
He has beene alwayes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will speake to her,
Though death in the Dukes eye threatens to kill me,
Great Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: You doe not well Leontio to insult
Upon my misery, Dionisios frowne
May make your feild as barren.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By all vertue,
And by your selfe the Mistris, I have not
One thought so irreligious in my soule
I weepe for your misfortune, and shall Study
All humble wayes to serve you.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: You have beene noble.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your titles are all sacred still with me,
The Dukes neglect cannot unprince you here;
Oh let not hasty sorrow boast a triumph
Over so great a mind, let not that beauty
Whither with apprehension of your wrong
That may be soone repented, and the Storme
That cowardly would shake that comliest building
Make for your happines, some lament your fate.
Whose lookes speake mirth, be confident, the Duke
Will chide the unlawfull flame, that like rude
And wandring meteor, led him from your vertues
With so much danger to embrace Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: The Duke shall know your complements.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Noe more, least for your charity to me,
For I must call it so, you ruine not
Your favour with the Duke, farewell Leontio
Yet I would pray one favour from you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Me?
My life's your servant.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: If you heare the Duke
Speake of me, as I feare he never will
But in displeasure, tell him I will thinke it
Noe cruelty to take this poore life from me,
Rather then let me draw a wretched breath
With generall scorne, let him command me dead,
And I forgive him, otherwise farewell.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That close shewed something, like a will to be,
Reveng'd her brest heav'd up, and fell againe,
While both her eyes shot a contention upward,
As they would seeme to put just Heaven in mind
How much she suffers.
If griefe thus become her,
What magicke will not love put on? I must
Stifle my passion. Pallante, welcome,
You are well met in Court;
Where dost thou live Pallante?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Every where,
Yet no where to any purpose, we are out
Of use, and like our Engines are laid by
To gather dust, the Court I ha'not skill in,
I want the tricke of flatterie, my Lord,
I cannot bow to Scarlet, and Gold-lace,
Embroiderie is not an Idoll for my worship,
Give me the warres agen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But yet remember we fight for peace,
The end of warre.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I never did, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Fight for peace, I fought for pay, and honour,
Peace will undoe us.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Tis the corruption of our peace, that men
Glorious in Spirit, and desert, are not
Encourag'd.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: The faults somewhere.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I presume
Thou art not of so tyrannous a nature,
But thou couldst be content to weare rich cloathes,
Feed high, and want no fortune without venturing
To buy them at the price of blood.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I could.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And ile engage thou sha't, be this the Prologue.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Not I, keepe, keepe your money.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You doe not scorne my bounty.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: You may guesse
That fortune has not doted much upon mee,
And yet I must refuse it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your reason pray?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Why ten to one I shall spend it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So tis meant.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: 'Twill make me gay a while, but I shall pawne
My Robes, and put on these agen,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou sha't not
While I have Fortune to preserve thee otherwise,

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I say out of my love to you I must not,
I never yet tooke money upon charity,
I earn'd it in the Warre, and I'le deserue't
In peace, of you I cannot, tis my misery
To be unserviceable.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is that your Scruple?
But that I know thy humor, I should thinke
This cunning, but you shall not, Sr, despaire,
I shall find wayes to have mention'd
In your accounts for merrits, doubt not, I
Will give you occasion to deserve more.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: On those conditions i'le take more, and thinke the better
Of my owne life, honour'd by your imployments.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Duke.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ha? Leontio.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: If I have any braynes, he shew'd a passion
Did not become him to your Dutches Sr.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Presumes he on his blood, above our favour?
Dares he but in a thought controule our pleasure,
No more, wee'le take noe knowledge, oh my Lord
You absent your selfe too much, though we confesse
Our State must owe much to your care, we would not
Your offices should wast you with imployments
Preserve your health I pray—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I never did
Enioy it more then when I studied service,
And duties to your grace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Musicke, the minuits
Are sad i'th absence of Ardelia,
And moove too slow, quicken their pace with Luts,
And voices.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more; we will be Musicke of our selves,
And spare your Arts, thought of Ardelia,
Should strike a harmony through every heart,
What brow lookes sad, when we command delight?
We shall account that man a Traytor to us,
That weares one sullen Cloud upon his face,
I'le read his soule in't, and by our bright Mistresse,
Then which the World containes noe richer beauty,
Punish his daring sinne.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He will deserve it
Great Sir, that shall offend with the least sadnes,
Or were it so possest, yet your command
That stretches to the soule, would make it smile,
And force a bravery, severe old age
Shall lay aside his sullen gravity,
And revell like a youth, the froward Matrons
For this day, shall repent their yeares, and coldnes
Of blood, and wish agen their tempting beauties
To dance like wanton Lovers.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My Leontio,
In this then thou dost present our bosome to thee,
What's he?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A Gentleman that has deserv'd
For service in your late warres, Sir, a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He may turne Courtier now, we have no use
Of noyse, we can march here without a Drumme,
I hope we are not in arreares to him,
He haunts us for noe pay?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your bounty beside that, hath wonne their hearts.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why has he noe better cloathes? this is a day
Of Triumph.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I beseech your highnes pardon,
I ha' drunke your health in better cloathes, dispise
My Christian Buffe; this is the fruits of peace,
I'le waite on you agen.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Wher's my Ardelia?
How at the name my spirits leape within me,
And the amorous winds doe catch it from my lips
To sweeten the Ayre— heaven at the sound
Lookes cleare, and lovely, and the earth put's on
A spring to welcome it, speake Leontio
Strozzi, Gentlemen, but she appeares.
For whom the World shall weare eternall shiue,
Brightest Ardelia, Queene of love, and me,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The onely honor, my ambition climes too,
Is to be held your highnes humblest hand-maid.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Call me thy servant, what
New charmes her lookes does throw upon my soule.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How the Duke gazes?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: There is some strange divinity within her,
Is there not Valerio?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am not read so farre yet as divinity,
Mine is but humane learning.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Speake agen,
And at thy lipps the quires shall hang to learne
New tunes, and the dull spheres but coldly imitate,
I am transform'd with my excesse of rapture,
Frowne, frowne Ardelia I shall forget
I am mortall else, and when thou hast throwne downe
Thy servant, with one smile exalt agen
His heart to heaven, and with a kisse breath in me
Another soule fit for thy love, but all
My language is too could, and we wast time,
Lead on, ther's something of more ceremony
Expects our presence, Italy is barren
Of what we wish to entertaine Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: May all the pleasures thought can reach attend you.

div.head: Actus Secundus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: BE counsell'd yet without being too ambitious
To buy a deere repentance.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Now we are.
Arriv'd at Court, shame to our resolution,
I prethee do'nt tempt me to such cowardise,
Horatio I must see her, sheele not blast us,
She was lovely when our eyes saluted last,
And at my fare-well many innocent teares
Wittness'd her sorrow, cleere as Aprill weepes
Into the bosome of the Spring, not see
Ardelia?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You have travel'd since, and she
Wanting noe beauty, was not over willing
To languish in your absence, how I pity thee,
But that I wod not too much vexe your folly,
Do'st thinke ther's faith in any womans eyes,
She wept at parting, a strong obligation
When they can thread their teares, and make a chaine
Of water, let me weare one o' their bracelets;
I will convince thy madnes in six words,
Admit she said she lov'd you, and to your thinking
Vow'd it, for you say you were contracted
All this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not this; although
You had beene married, and i'th Sheets together,
And chaffer'd earnest for a boy, 'tis nothing
It binds not.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not with a thousand witnesses.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How not bind her?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nor any woman living, that's possest
With a wandring spirit, clap her in a dungeon,
Pile three Castles on her, yet she shall
Breake prison when she has but the least minde too't;
She le worke through a Steele-mine, to meete a friend
That she likes better, with more ease throw up
A quarrie of Marble, than a Mole shall dust,
They worke with spirits, man, and can doe wonders,
Especially a hansome woman, from whose false
And sly temptations, all my wits defend me.
There were some dealing with an Elvish female,
That had but a course face, or say but halfe a one,
Emnaticke eyes, with no more sight than could
Distinguish well, man from a horse, or beare,
To keepe her from mistake in procreation,
A nose of many fashions, and as many
Water-workes in 'em, lips of honest hide,
And made to last, teeth of a Moores complexion,
A chinne, without all controversie, good
To goe a fishing with, a witches beard on't,
With twentie other commendations, such a thing
Were no mischiefe, and a man might trust
Her with no scruple in his Conscience.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This is plaine madnesse.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You may call it so,
But Ile be bound to travell further with
This Night-mare, than the finest flesh and blood
You court, and call your mistresse, why the Devill
With all his art, and malice will nere cuckold me,
And I should leave her in hell, and goe a journey,
I should be sure at my returne to find her
Safe, and untouch'd, sound of her winde, and limbs;
A faire, and hansome woman would not scape so:
You have my opinion now, and 'twere lesse evill
To practise it, you mind not my instructions.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: These Lectures have L read toth' City
With the same successe, that Gentlemen might live honest,
And men have lucke to father their owne children,
But 'twill not be, you are resolv'd to try it?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Am I engag'd thus farre to fall backe now?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Remember where you are yet.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I am i'th Court.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Where you expect to complement with the Dukes—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What doe you thinke? the Dukes married,
They say although he love Ardelia,
And without question, in these parts may want
No intelligence of your purpose, and your person,
And theres no doubt, but if he find you quaile-catching,
He has power enough to coole your blood, and hers,
Should she remember what has past betweene you,
In that respect be caution'd, doe not worke
A double ruine, to sooth one vaine humour;
Eyes will beget an appetite of more neerenesse,
And how that may succed, 'tis better feare, than prove.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I prethee fright me not with shadowes.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You are then for her substance— Ile not leave you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ile see her did the Duke proclaime it death.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I Had rather see the Cow, with her five legges,
And all the Monsters in the market, then
Be troubled with the spectacle, but on,
Stay, yet will you but see her? will her face content you,
A farre off, without multiplying twinckles,
Ridiculous sighes, or crost armes pinion'd thus,
As the Kinght-Templers leggs are, whollie buried,
Like Taylors, no djected lookes, as y'ad
Your father alive agen to send you out
To sea, with pention to maintaine you in bisket,
Poore John, and halfe a livery, which should be
Part of your governor, to read morrall vertue
And lenton Lectures to you, or if she frowne
As much as say my friend, I am not for you,
The Dukes the better Gentleman, and shall pay for't
Will you returne then with a handsome patience,
And wisely love where no man els will rivall you,
A Witch or some old woman,

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I prethee leave
Thy phrenzy, thou shal't witnes ile be temperate.
Who's this? Signior Valerio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Bentivolio, welcome to
Pavie, and the Court.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My friend, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You both divide me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Then I am no stranger,
In confidence of that friendship we both seal'd
In Travell.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What affaires brought you to Pavie?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Being at large, I had curiositie
To observe what might improve my knowledge here
With some taste of your Court.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And I am happie
I have some power to serve your wish, nor could you
Arrive to see it shine with more delight,
It is compos'd of revells, now all ayre,
Let me present you to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I shall be honour'd to kisse his hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sha't see his Mistresse,
The faire Ardelia, the Dukes no saint,
I may tell thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Pray Sir, with your favour,
Cannot the Court furnish a Gentleman,
And need be, with an uglie face or two,
Such as would turne your stomacke, would content
My fancie best.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What meanes your friend?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: A humour he playes withall.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: He would not play with such a woman, wo'd he?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, and if the place be not
Too barren to afford me one ill-favoured
Enough.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nere feare it, they are common here
As Crowes, and something of a hue by moone-shine
Promise to keepe your wits, and ile present you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I have a lease Sir, of my braines, and dare
Enconnter with an armie out of Lapland.

div.stage: Enter the Duke, Ardelia, Fiametta, Leontio, Strozzi, Ascanio, Silvio, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: How likes Ardelia this?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: If it affect
Your highnesse eare, dutie hath so compos'd
My will to obedience, I must praise the musicke,
And wish no other object to that sence,
Unlesse you please to expresse more harmonie
By some commands from your owne voice, that will
Challenge my more religious attention.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What charme is in her language? cease all other
(But discord to her accents) what a sweet,
And winning soule she has, is it not pity
She should be lesse than Dutchesse, farre above
Euphemia in beautie, and rare softnesse
Of nature, I could wonder, gaze for ever;
But I expose my passion too much
To censure, yet who dares dispute our will?
Leontio looke upon Ardelia,
And tell me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Canst see nothing there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I see a spacious field of beautie Sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Tis poore, and short of her perfection,
Beare her this other Jewell, I will have her
Shine like a volumne of bright constellations,
Till all the world turne her Idolater:
When did Euphemia looke thus?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Never sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Be Judge thy selfe Leontio, if my Dutches
Lov'd me, could she denie her Dionisio
This happinesse, but she has a stubborne soule.
She has, and shall repent it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, remember
Shee is a princesse.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You were best remember her,
Perhaps sheele take it kindlie.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, I hope
You have more assurance of my faith to you
Then to interpret—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nothing, come, all's well,
Name her noe more, how ere she has displeas'd
Us, you can violate noe duty still
To love her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I sir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This infects delight,
Let's dance my sweete Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Dukes jealous
Or i'me batraid.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Leontio, Silvio, Strozzi,
The Ladies blush for you, they have breath'd too much.

div.stage: While the Dance is Enter Valerio, Bentivolio, Horatio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, here are gentlemen desire the grace
To kisse your highnesse hand.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ardelia supply our Dutchesse absence,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is the Dukes desire by his example, you extend your
Faire hand to a payre of strangers, ambitions of the
Honour.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Bentivolio?
Tis he, how my heart trembles as my frame
Would fall to peeces, doe you know that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let him attend me in my lodgings
It will be worth your friend-ship to conduct him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Your countenance changes, I observ'd
Your eyes upon that Stranger.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He revewes
The memory of a brother, I lov'd dearely,
That died at Sea: I ne're saw two so like.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: For representing one so neare Ardelia,
Receive another welcome, and what favours
Your thoughts can study from our Court, possesse 'em.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You oblige my humblest services— how now, how dost like this?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Why scuruily, you flatter
Your selfe into distruction, I see
The Arrow will peirce thy heart, decline it yet.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Still frantickely opposing.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I ha' done
Be mad, i'le give my braine to somewhat els,
Sir, I'wod see a phisnomy, though it looke
As big as the fower winds, I ha' court-ship for it,
And wo not he blowne off with an Hericano,
Yet trust me i'le be honest.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I beleeve you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Onely to please my eye.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What thinke you of
That Divells lans-schape, you observ'd not her,
Notwithstanding her complexion, she is a Lady
Usefull at Court, to set of other faces,
Especially the Dukes Mistres, whom for that,
And some thing else his grace has recommended
To be her companion, will she serve turne?
Did you ever see a more excellent wall-eye

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I marry, Sir.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Nay let me prepare you,
Madam dee observe that Gentleman,
The hearing Stranger, he has busines to you,
And you will bid it welcome.

sp.speaker: Fi.
sp.l: Does he know me?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: He inquir'd for you
By all discriptions— and I guesse he may
Be worth your favour.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Mine?

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: If ever man
Were an Jdolater, he is yours, i'le bring him
To your lodgings Madam, if you please.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: You'le honour me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Agen to our revells, ther's noe life without being active,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not now? you shall have opportunity,
And I have commission to informe you something,

div.l: Away here's like to be a Storme.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What's shee?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Euphemia.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Your Dutches, Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How dares shee interrupt us?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A guard about my heart, I am undone e'ls.
Each looke, and motion in her greife present
Such a commanding sweetnes, if I observe
With the same eyes I shall betray my selfe.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: I come not Sir, with rudenes of my language,
Or person to offend your mirth, although
the nature of my sorrow is so wild
It may infect weake minds, and such as have not
Some proofe in their owne bosomes, but to make
One, and my last suite, which when you have heard
It may appeare so reasonable, and proportion'd
To what your thoughts allow me, that you will
Find easily a consent to make it fortunate,
And me in the prevailing.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Doe not moove.
Ardelia, I am full protection here.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Ther's something sir in my request to make her happy too,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I dare not heare the Dutchesse,
Her lookes wound me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Speake your promising wishes.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Although I know not for what guilt in me
Of more then my obedience, and some lesse
Beauty then dwells upon Ardelias cheeke,
You have exild me from your love, and bosome,
And worse then one condemn'd by force of lawes,
For sinne against your bed have sentenc'd me
To wander with disgrace, carv'd in my brow
The Fable of a Dutchesse, and your anger;
My desires are you would have so much charity
Though you have made me an out-law by your doome,
Not to compell me after all my shames
To be a murderer.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Treason, our Guard.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: You shall not trouble Sir your feares I bring
the least blacke thought against your person, heaven
Avert so foule à sinne, the danger all
Doth threaten me, and my life, which I thus
Most humbly beg may not be forc'd through blood
By my owne hands urgd by your heavy wrongs
To such a desperate mutiny, which you may
Prevent by your revenge of Law upon me.
To which, and your displeasure I would yeild
My life your welcome sacrifice, i'le praise
Your mercy for my death, and blesse the stroake
Devids my sad soule from me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This your project?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Did you heare the Dutches suite?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Noe, but i'le beg
It may be granted, doe not sir deny
Your Dutches her desires so just, and reasonable;

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How's this? shee'le pray to be rid on her,
Audacious woman

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Let me rise with horror.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ardelia knowes not what Euphemia ask'd.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: She'le appeare cunning.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I am confident
She hath propounded nothing ill becoming.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nothing, a very trifle, wearied with
Her injuries she onely begs the Duke
Would be so kind to order with as much
Conveniency as he please, her head to be
Chop'd of, that all, and you were charitable
To joyne so modestly in the advancement
Of her desires.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Defend it heaven,
Madam your pardon, I imagin'd not
You aym'd such cruelty upon your selfe.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Proud, and dissembling woman, at such impudence
I take my spirit to me, and no more
Will put my breath to the expence of prayer
To be short-liv'd, I will desire to live
To see heaven drop downe justice, with such loud,
And publicke noyse of my revenge on thee,
And thy adulterate arts, as the world naming
But once Ardelia, shall be palsey-strucke.
I feele a new, and fiery soule within me,
Apt to disperse my rage, which feare and my
Religion would ha' stifled. Oh my fate!

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She raves, to prison with her, we are not safe
While she enjoyes the freedome of our ayre:
Stay (my good Genius) she carries yet
The title of our Dutches; tis our pleasure
Leontio, she be your prisoner,
But see her narrowlie confind, till we
Determine what shall follow, in what we
Limit, you not make your owne reason guide,
But on your life secure her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your commands
In all things I obey, most blest occasion!

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Foole, thou dost entertain what must undo thee,
And make you both ripe for eternall absence;
Hug Juno in the clouds, and court her smiles,
Though she consent not, tis enough youl stand
Suspected, and expos'd to equall danger.
You sha'not lose your ayre to plead for death,
Thus wele secure Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: I heare,
And with all chearefullnesse resigne my will
To imprisonment, or death; forgive the wildnesse,
And furie of my language, I repent
My wish upon Ardelia, may she live
To doe so too, and you to be possest
Of all joyes, Earth and Heaven can blesse your heart with
May danger never in a dreame affright you,
And if you thinke I live too long, tis possible,
Before you send death to conclude my sufferings,
Some thoughts of you may wither my poore heart,
And make your path smooth, to what most you joy in
Be not a tyrant when i'me dead, upon
My fame, although you wish me not alive,
Yet say I was Euphemia, let that sticke
Upon my Tombe, if you will grace my shade
With so much cost, in that name is supplied
Enough to tell the world for whom I died.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We heare too much, away with her.

div.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I Have given a treasure to your bosome Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You shannot friend repent it, and this act
Of so much confidence, new binds my faith to you;
Contracted to Ardelia? I may chance make use of this.
Your pilgrimage ends here—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Doe you know
What you have done?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I have told him what
Concern'd Ardelia, and my selfe; thou wod'st
Suspect, and chide my credulous nature, come,
Ile trust him with my life.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That's done already,
He has a secret, much good doe him wo't,
Should ha' burnt a passage through my heart, and left
It ashes, ere th'ad wandred from me thus,
And if you never did before, pray now
He may be honest to you, tis too late
To finde compunction for it, pray, and heartily
He may be dumbe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Signior Bentivolio?
So, so, thats over, now ile conduct you
To your pretious Saint, unlesse your bloud turne
Coward.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ob, never feare it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But would you did
First tell me and discharge me of some wonder,
You have an humor of the newest fashion
I ere yet saw, and how the Court may follow't
I know not, how long have you beene possest Sir?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Possest? what Divell doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With these ilfavour'd, deform'd women, y'are bewitchd sure?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thou dost not know the fiends I have convers'd with.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: I have no ambition to be acquainted
With any Goblins, further then their knowledge
Might make me understand the ground of your
Inchantment.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Oh a world, Legions, Legions.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Of hansome women.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They the cause of this?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Their false, and periur'd natures, I nere met with
One hansome Face that made a conscience of me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Anddee' thinke to finde
More Faith in those that looke all ore like Devills?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Tis possible they may have soules, who knowes?
Howe're in my revenge, ile love, and doate on 'em,
And iustifie thy are the Sexes glorie.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have enough.
They are return'd, this way Sir, to your Fayrie.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My dearest Bentivolio, why dost stand
At so much gaze, and distance, as thou wod'st
Teach love unkindnesse, can these out ward formes
Disguise me from thy knowledge, lets salute,
My lips retaine their softnesse, and unles
Thy love be chang'd, our breath may meet, and we
Convey the heartie meaning of our soules,
As we once did.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Y'are very brave Ardelia,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: But have no pride without you, these are no
Glories compar'd to what I weare within,
To see thee safe, whom my feares gave up lost,
And after so much absence, doe I live
To embrace my Bentivolio?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You would have me
Beleeve J am welcome hither, faire Ardelia,
Pardon, I know not yet what other name
To call you by, and if I wrong your titles,
Be gentle to my ignorance; this hand
You gave me once, when no ambition frighted
The troth we vow'd, our chast simplicity
Durst kisse without a shame, or feare to be
Divorc'd by greatnes, tell me, sweet Ardelia,
When I did court thy Virgin faith, and paid
An innocent tribute to thy most chast lip,
When we had spent the day with our discourse,
And night came rudely in to part us, what
Were then thy usuall dreames? how many visions
Were let into thy sleepe, thou shouldst be great,
Torne from my bosome, to enrich thy selfe,
And a Dukes armes? and that a time should come,
When I, the promisd Master of this wealth,
Should thus present my selfe a beggar to thee,
And count thy smiles a charitie?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: What meanes
My Bentivolio by this passionate language?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I doe confesse I was compell'd to be
An exile from thee, in obedience to
My father, who would trust me to the Seas,
Or any land, ere leave me to this shipwracke,
For so his anger sinn'd against thy beautie,
Whilst the Idoll Gold grac'd not thy fairer Temple,
Yet when we plighted hearts, Ardelia,
I tied with mine an everlasting contract,
And did expect at my returne to have found
Thine spotles.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Tis the same.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The same to me?
What makes you here then? doe not, doe not flatter
Thy guilt so much. Is not this Pavias Court?
Ardelias Court indeed, for she rules here,
The Lady Paramount whilst the Duke himselfe
Bowes like a subject!

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Be not, Sir too credulous,
And with too apprehensive thoughts doe injury
To that which you should cherish, the Duke is—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Youle say none of your subiect,
He is a prince,
Prince of your Province, writs Ardelia his,
Tis ravish'd all from me, and I am become
A stranger to my owne, nay stand, and see
My treasure rifled, all my wealth tane from me,
And dare not question the injurious power
That revells in my glory, but canst thinke
I will be cold for ever, that all seeds
Of man lie dead within me, and my soule
Sunke in my phlegme, will never rise to forme
Some iust revenge? thinke there are then noe furies.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: You come to threaten not to love, and having
Already by long absence made a fault,
To quit your selfe would lay a staine on me,
Tis not well done.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Duke.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The Duke?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Tis possible
He may not feare your anger.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I'le squat then
Behind this Hedge, this Garden hath quient shades,
I hope you'le not betray me.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: This the forme
Of your revenge,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My faire Ardelia
Excuse me if I presse upon thy private
Walkes, love gives a bouldnes to meane spirits,
But in a Princes brest: tis much more active,
And feares noe imputation, what doth fright
Thy countenance? I hope Ardelia
My presence brings noe horror.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Sir, much comfort,
Whether it were my fancie or a truth
I know not.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: You have noe satires
Within this ground, doe any haunte this Garden?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Satiers?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: As I have read 'em character'd,
So one appear'd, or I imagin'd so,
And as you entred hid himselfe, they are
Halfe men——

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Halfe beasts.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: With Goats hornes in their fore-head,
The thought on't troubles me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The effect onely of melancholie thoughts,
Noe such things are
In nature, yet i'le search, and— strange apprehension.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Twas more then shape, sure it did talke to me,
And threaten me for your sake.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How? for mine?
I'le have the Trees, and Arbors all torne up,
Divels lurke here? the earth shall not secure 'em,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: He said he lov'd me, and accus'd my heart
Of periury, as we had beene contracted.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: More strange! my guard!

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Stay sir, before you goe
Let me beseech your iustice in defence
Of my much iniur'd honour, as you are
A Prince, I doe beseech you speake all truth,
For let him be the Divell, I'le not have
My innocence abus'd, I know not from
What fame, or fond opinion voic'd of me,
By some that had more thought to serve your will
Then vertue, I was made beleeve you lov'd me,
Which though my force resisted by some practises,
You gaind my person hither, and in Court
Command my stay.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Entreat, my best Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You may Sir, smooth your cause, but I can fetch
A witnes from my bosome to convince
The truth I urge, yet let me not be lost
To gratitude, my soule bids me acknowledge
Never was subiect to a Prince more bound
For free, and beauteous graces, then Ardelia
To your highnes, and with many lives to wast
In service for them, I were still in debt to you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Tis in thy power to satisfie for all,
And leave me ten times more oblig'd to thee.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let me for this time beg on answer from you,
Although I am not ignorant, what price
Your wild bloud would exact, speake in the eare
Of silent heaven, have you obteyn'd so much
As one stoope to your wanton avarice,
One bend to please your inflam'd appetite.

sp.speaker: Du
sp.l: Not any yet, the more unkind Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Speake clearely by the honour of a Prince.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: By better hopes I sweare, and by thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You doe me Sir, but Justice, I will study
To pay my humblest duty, and i'le tell
When next I see the Satire——

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: To discharge those feares, i'le presently destroy,
This Garden, and not leave shelter,
For a Bird.

sp.speaker: Ar
sp.l: Your pardon,
To what wo'd my immagination lead me?
I see all was but melancholie, here was nothing.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Fruits of a troubled fancie, come be pleasant,
And tell me when you will redeeme your cruelty,
It may incline you somewhat to remember
By what soft wayes I have persued your love,
How nobly I would serue you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Love, your grace
Knowes, never was compelld.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But love should find
Compassion to the wound it makes, I bleed,
And court thy gentle pity to my sufferings,
All Princes are not of so calme a temper,
Thinke of it my Ardelia, and reward
The modest expectations of a heart,
That in thy absence withers, but i'le have thee
To chide thy cruell thoughts, and till our lipps
Salute agen, flatter my selfe with hope
Thy nature will be wise, and kind to love,
Where tis so fairely courted.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Is he gone?
With what acknowledgment of my fault Ardelia
Shall I beseech thy pardon, I am lost
In wonder of thy innocence; 'twere just
I should suspect the truth of my owne bosome,
Thou hast too rich a goodnes.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now you flatter,
I knew noe way o'th suddaine to convince you,
But by the Dukes confession, I am yet
Preseru'd my Bentivolio, but with what
Danger of being lost to thee, and honour
I shall remaine here, may concerne our Jealousie,

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Together with the knowledge of thy vertue
Like balsome powr'd into my eare, I tooke
A poyson from the Duke, I find he loves thee
With a blacke purpose, and within his language
Was something worth our feare indeede, it will
Require our study, and much art, Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let's retire into my chamber, and mature
Some course for both our safeties.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I attend you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I wo'not stay three minutes, ile but step aside for distillation. I leave you the pleasure of your eyes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Well, goe thy waies.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Doe you not mocke me Sir, shall I beleeve
A Gentleman of your neate, and elegant making,
Can stoope to such a creature as I am.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Will you have me sweare?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: By no meanes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Then I wo'not,
But I will give it thee under my hand,
Read that.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Something to shew I hate all hansome women.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Is't a song?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It may be, with a voice, and tune put too't,
Ile reade it.

div.stage: Enter Ualerio, with Aurelia, and Macrina veild.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: L am come agen Sir, and choose, rather then
To afflict you with expectation,
To bring my company along, you may
Salute 'em if you please.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: They are not welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you beleeve me now?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: If we may trust our eies.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ladies you must excuse me, I affect
No vulgar beauties, give me a complexion
Cannot be match'd agen in twenty kingdomes,
You have eies, and nose, and lips, and other parts
Proportion'd.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sure the Gentlemans distracted.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No, I am recover'd, I thanke my starres,
To know, and heartily abhorre such faces,
What come they hither for?dee' know 'em Madam?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I had no purpose they should be my guests
At this time, th'are court Ladies, I confesse,
Signior Valerio this was your plot.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: My pure intention, Madam, to doe you
Service, I knew they were not for his pallate,
These will inflame his appetite to you,
And set you off, meere foiles to you doe they
Looke as they were ambitious to be
Compar'd with you.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Noble sir, although
I have not beautie like these Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ho
sp.l: How? you ha' not beautie, take heed doe not shew
Your selfe unthankfull to wise nature, do not
They ha' not wealth enough in all their bodies
To purchase such a nose.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ha, ha, good Madam Kick shaw,
That laugh to shew how many teeth you have.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Be not uncivill Sir.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Why does that Fayrie grin then?
I'le justifie there is more worth, and beautie,
Consider'd wisely, and as it preserves
Man in his wits, and sence, than can be read
I'th volumne of their flattering Generations.
Good Madam looke a squint, a little more,
So, keepe but that cast with your eies, and tell me
Whose sight is best, hers that can see at once
More severall waies then there are points i'th Com-passe,
Or theirs that lookes but point-blancke.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: A new way
To commend the eies.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You thinke your fore-head pleases.
Whose top with frizled, and curld haire beset,
Appeares like a white cliffe, with reeds upon't;
Your nose, which like an Isthmus parts two Seas.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Seas? you meane eies agen.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: What of their nose?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Will be in danger, with continuall beating
Of waves, to wash the paint off, and in time
May fall, and put you to the charge of building
A silver bridge for praises to passe over.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: We'l barre your commendations.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It sha'not need,
I doe not melt my wits to verse upon
Such subject, here's an instrument to smell with,
Tough as an Elephants trunke, and will hold water.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It has a comely length, and is well studded
With gems of price, the gold-smith wo'd bid money for't.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is he not mad?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I can assure you no,
And by this token I would rather be
Condemn'd to'th Gallies, then be once in love
With either of your phisnomies.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You may put your whole faith upon't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dee' beleeve him?
Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Methinkes this is the prettiest mirth,
You have a mighty wit, could you be angry
I love you for't.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: His humor takes me infinitely.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It does, and you doe love me for't?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Most strangely.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I would you did, and heartily.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Love me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: So well, I could be happy in thy wife.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Could Fate make me so miserable if I did not
In lesse than a sennight breake thy heart, shu'dst
Cuck old me at my owne perill.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This Lady has
A mightie estate.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Tis all the fault she has,
Would she had none, had she no house, nor clothes,
Nor meanes to feed, yet I would sooner marry,
Observe, this naked salvage, then embrace
The fairest woman of the earth, with power
To make me Lord of Italy, I should alwayes
Enjoy my health.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her very face would keepe
Your bodie soluble.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No feares compell me
To be a prisoner to my dining-roome,
I might hawke, hunt, and travell to both Indies.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Give any Doctor leave to give her Phisicke.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Or change of Ayre.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Save much in your owne diet,
Which else would call for Amber-greece, and rootes,
And stirring cullices.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You might allow her
To visit Maskes and Playes.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: And the Bordellos,
I thinke she would be honest.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And thats more
Then any Christian conscience dare assure
By oath on your behalfe to be short Ladies,
Howe're you may interpret it my humour,
Mine's a Platonicke love, give me the soule,
I care not what course flesh, and blood inshrine it;
Preserve your beauties, this will feare no blasting:
I beg you call me servant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Did you heare him?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: You must acknowledge then I am your Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ile weare your Perriwig for my Plume, and boast
More honour int, than to be minion
To all the Ladies of the Court, deere Mistresse
If you can love a man, jeere 'em a little.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Faire Ladies will you in, and taste a banquet,
Be not discountenanc'd that this Gentleman
Is merrie with your beauties the Spring lasts
Not all the yeare, when nature that commands
Our regiment will say, faces about,
We may bee in fashion, no controwling destiny.
Passion, who curld your haire? here wanteth powder,
Who is your Mercer, Madam? I would know
What your cheeke stands you in a weeke in Taffata?
Your face at distance shewes like spotted Ermine.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Or like a dish of white-broth strew'd with Currains.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Right servant, that was a more proper simily,
Discretion should ha put more ceruse here,
Your fucus was ill made, d'ee you not lie
In a maske all night, Madam.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Thou dost in a vizard
I will be sworne how the rude Gipsie triumphs

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Enough, they now begin to swell, and sweate,
Let's leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What a Hecate was this?
Will you not be reveng'd?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes, if we knew
By what convenient stratagem.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I have it,
There is another creature of my acquaintance,
If you have faith more monstrous then this beldam,
I will possesse her with this gentlemans humor,
And skrew her up to be this witches rivall, what thinke you of that?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Will it not make her mad?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I wo'd goe a pilgrimage to see't, 'twill be
A mirth beyond the Beares.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Loose no time then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le fit him with a female fury, such
As the Divell with a pitch-forke will not touch.
Come Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Have comfort Madam,
I prophecy your sufferings are short-liv'd.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: You meane I shall die shortly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We shall find
Lesse want of all the Starres, the aged World
May spare their light, while 'tis possest of yours,
Which once extinguish'd, let those golden fires
Quite burne themselves to ashes, in whose heape
Day may be lost, and frighted heaven weare blacke
Before the generall doome, have bolder thoughts,
And bid us all live in your onely safety.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Let not your fancy mocke the lost Euphemia?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let not the apprehension of your sorrow
Destroy your hope, should the Duke never wake
His sences steep'd in his adulterate lethargy
You cannot want protection, nor your will
To be reveng'd, an arme to punish his
Contempt of so much beauty.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: How my Lord?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What Scithian can behold an outrage done
Upon these eyes, and not melt his rough nature
In soft compassion to attend your teares?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: My Lord I know not with what words to thanke
Your feeling of my sufferings. I will now
Beleeve I am not lost to all the World;
You are noble, and I must be confident
These streames flow from your charity.

sp.speaker: Loe.
sp.l: Doe not injure
The unvalued wealth of your owne honour Madam,
Let pore deserts be worth our charity,
All sacrifice of greife for you is Justice,
And duty to the Alter of your merrit,
These drops are pale, and poorely speake my heart,
Which should dissolve into a purple flood,
And drowne this little Iland in your service,
Name some imployment that you may beleeve
With what true soule I honour you, oh Madam
If you could read the Volume of my heart,
You would find such a story of you there.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Of me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Tis that keepes me alive, I have noe use
Of memory or reason, but in both
To exercise devotion to your excellence.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: My Lord I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are
More apprehensive if you wod but thinke so,
In vaine I still suppreste my darke thoughts Madam,
Which in their mutiny to be reveal'd
Have left a heape of ruines worth your pity.
Oh doe not hide that beauty should repaire
What my love to it hath decay'd within me,
For I must say I love, although you kill
My ambition with a frowne; and with one angry
Lightning, shot from your eye, turne me to ashes.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Good heaven!

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.l: I know what you will urge against me,
You shannot need to arme your passion,
I will accuse my selfe, how much I have
Forgot the distance of one place beneath you,
And wounded my obedience, that I am
False to the Duke, the trust impos'd upon me,
And to his favor which have made me shine
A Starre, on whom the other emulous lights
Looke pale, and wast their envies, I confesse
I have not in the stocke of my desert
Enough to call one bounteous smile upon me,
My whole life is not worth your liberall patience,
Of one, one minute spent in prayer to serue it,
Yet after all wish'd destiny commands
The poore Leontio to love Euphemia.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: What doe I heare? consider sir againe.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: I have had contentions with my blood, & forc'd
Nature retire, and tremble with the guilt
Of her proud thoughts, seeking to make escape
Through some ungentle breatch made by our conflict
But noe prevailing against love, and fate,
Which both decree, me lost without your mercie.
Oh bid me live, who but in your acceptance
Shall grone away my breath, and whither till
I turne my owne sad monument.

sp.speaker: Fup.
sp.l: Noe more,
Ist possible new miseries should oretake
Euphemia? Oh my Lord I with what offence
Have I deserv'd, after my weight of sorrow,
Your wounds upon my honour? call agen
Your noble thoughts, and let me not reply
To your vnjust desires, if I must answer them,
Take my most fixt resolve, er'e I consent
To wrong Diovisio.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: May: be blasted,
Though with contempt he looke upon me now,
His blood may cleare, and he returne to challenge
Euphemias prety, our vow was made
For life my Lord, and heaven shall sooner fall,
And mixing with the elements make new Chaos,
Then all mans violence, and wrath upon me
Betray one thought to breake it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Loose not all
Your peace at once, vouchsafe I may waite on you.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: I know my prison.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let me hope in this,
My pardon seal'd Pallante?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your humble creature Madam, though the Duke
Confine your person, thinke upon your prisoner.
Our vow was made for life, 'twas so how swift
An apprehension love has? but hee's Duke;
Conscience be waking, I shall lanch into
A Sea of blood els, steere my desperate soule
Diviner goodnes.
How I start at shaddowes?
Love take me to thy charmes, and prosper me
Pallante thou art faithfull.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: To you my Lord,
May I be ever els condemn'd to an Hospitall.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And darst assist to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Yes,
Though with the hazard of my throat-cutting,
I hope Sir, you suspect not, name an action
Though it looke nere so gastly, see how much
I'le tremble at it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: In thy eare.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Once more
Tough service i'th beginning, may I not thinke on't?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: And aske my selfe a question ere I answere.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You may.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: At first dash kill the Duke, no lesse
To begin withall, how now Leontio?
Was there no other life but this, for saving
Of mine so often? he has trusted me,
To whom shall I turne traitor? pray my Lord,
Are you in earnest? would you have this done?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Aske one, whom tyrannie hath chain'd to'th oare
For ever forfeited to slaverie.
Whether he would not file off his owne bondage,
And in the blood of him that ownes the Gally
Swimme to his freedome.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Doe you apprehend it
So necessary? why ile doe my poore endeavour,
Nay, tis but modest, if't concerne your Lordship
In that degree, Ile doo't, you will have some
Convenient care of me, when tis dispatchd,
He scorn'd my valiant Buffe, I thought upon't,
You are the next in blood, when Dionisio
Visits the wormes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou giv'st me a new life,
With the same care ile cherish thee Pallante.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: And you doe not,
It is not the first conscience hath been cast
Away in a great mans service, cheere your heart Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It is not mine Pallante, I have lost
The use and sway, tis to anothers growne,
And I have but the ruines of my owne,

div.head: Actus Quartus.
div.stage: Enter Horatio, and Fiametta, dancing a Coranto.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: SO, so, now let's releeve our lungs a while,
They'l tire, I nere met with such a dancing Divell,
My Destinies take me to your charge, 'twill give
Us breath, if the Musitians exercise
Their voice upon the song I made, come sit.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: You shall command me servant, now, the song.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Lady Aurelia, Madam, and Macrina
Are come agen to visit you.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I am not
In tune for their discourse, say, I am busie.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: By no meanes, she has a plot upon me.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Then ile meet em.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Do not feare but I am fortified;
Here were a purchase now, and pension with
A Mistresse, many a proper mans profession,
Nature meant she should pay for't, and maintaine
A man in fidlers, fooles, and running-horses,
Here were no feare of any Lords returne
From Tennis, no suspition at home,
To force her to a politicke pilgrimage
To trie the vertue of some well, no kinsmen,
With lookes to keepe the flesh in a we, no children
To cry, and fright the house their mothers smother'd.
They are here.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I wonder at Valerios stay.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He wo'not be long absent, never feare madam.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ladies, I have no power to bid you welcome,
Or if I had you wod scarce thanke me for't,
You know my mind already.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: See hee's come,
And his Beare with him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Signior,
You see what care I have to provide for you,
There is not such another dapple-mare i'th Dukedome,
Unlesse this face content you, you may stay
Till the Cretan Lady goe to Bull againe,
Or Africke have more choice of Monsters for you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I am ravish'd.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: How's that servant ha? a rivall.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Pray whats her name?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her name is Scolopendra.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Scolopendra? I have read of her, what kinne is she
To the Serpent with a hundred legges?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know not
But she is Cosen-germane to the Salamander
She was a Cooke-maide once, so inu'rd to fire,
And tough, the flames of hell will hardly scortch her.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: An admirable Dragon, can she speake?
Will she not spit fire if I should salute her?
Ile venter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He has preservative
Against the odor of her lungs.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He had need
Of fortification for his eyes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not all
The spices in Arabia are like
Her breath.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh Sir, beleev't, right Stix, most pure Avernus.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: Sir, J did never see a Gentleman
Whom I did wish more heartily my husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To beget Scorpions on her.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thanke thee my pretious Scolopendra, but
I have a kind of feare thou wot be unconstant,
Shall noe man get thee from me; here's a face
Is worth my jealousie, and who lookes upon't,
But with my eyes will be as mad as I am.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: The needles not more constant to the North.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But for all that, the needles wavering
I would be certaine.

sp.speaker: Fia
sp.l: They conspir'd to wrong me,
I feare hee's taken with her more deformity,
Will you forsake me servant?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Humstand off,
And give my eyes play further yet, your shadowes
Are yet to neare— my judgment is confounded,
Consider one thing with another, they are both
Such matchles toads, I know not which to choose:
You have an excellent eye, but there's a pearle
In hers, noe Gold-smith knowes the value on't.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Observe the colours in my eye.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Y'are right Madam,
As many, and more bright then those i'th raine-bow
Delightfull as the Parrats plume, but then
Her for-head—

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: So like a promontory or—

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: A Feild of Hony-suckles, and Poppy-flowers
Embroder'd with Dazies, and emboss'd
With Yellow-warts which like to Mole-hills swell,

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Where many Emmets hunt, and sport themselve
I'th Sunne, till to her haire a quick set hedge
I'th evening they retire.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But twixt her eyes
You may discerne a Forrest, some higher timber
Is so well growne, that fashion'd on the top
With scissers and cut poynted like a pyramide,
The World will take her for an Unicorne.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Good beetle-browes.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: Sir, you must be my champion.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Examine but this nose.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: I have a toter.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Which plac'd with symmetry is like a Fountaine
I'th middle of her face— distilling Rhewme,
And at two spouts doth water all her Garden.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But here's one soft as 'twere compos'd of wax.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: A nose of wax.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: It will melt presently.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not stubborne, but submits to any shape,
Sheele put upon't round, flat when she is pleas'd
She can extend, and hang it with such art
Over her mouth, that when she gapes into
The Sunne, and shewes her Teeth, you will imagine
You see a perfect Dyall in her Chaps,
To tell you what a clocke tis, then her Lips.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I see not so much red there, as will make
A Dominicall Letter, looke upon these Cheekes—

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: I never painted, Sir.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Here's red enough.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Which hideously dispos'd, and mixt with blacke,
The ground of her complexion will mortefie
The most unnaturall concupiscence,
While her cheekes represent in curious Land-schape,
Gomorrah, and her sister Sodome burning.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: That comparison was home.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But she has a breath,
A more preservative then Methridate

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: But with one kisse she will preserve you from
The infection, and with stronger force repell
The poyson of the Ayre.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: I thanke you sir,
I have a strong breath 'indeed

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: When she is moov'd
Sheele kill you with her phlegme, fowerscore point blancke,
The innocent part of it will staine a Marble,
Let me alone to commend thee.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: She carries not destruction like my tongue
Employd upon thy enemies Horatio.
The Bells rung backwards, or the Mandrakes cry,
Wolves howling at the Moone, the Scritch-owles dirge,
The Hieus voice, the groanes of parting soules,
Added to these, what is in nature killing,
To the eare is not more fatall then my tongue
When it is bent on mischeife, shall I blast
This Witch to begin withall?

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: Blast me?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Belch back-wards,
And then shee's a dead woman.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: I'le teare your Snakes.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Mine Hecate.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Well said Scolopendra.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: They wonot skirmish.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: The Divells will runne at tilt.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Madam suffer this?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Compare with me?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Sa, sa, sa, now sound a point of Warre.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Madam the Duke.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: His grace has spoild the duell,
And we must sound retreat.

div.stage: All goe forth but Fiam. Enter Duke, Silvio, Ascanio, Valerio returns, and falls in with the rest.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We trusted to your art about Ardelia,
She makes noe hast to our delight.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: And please
Your highnes I have had a strange hand with her,
And I must tell you she was prety comming
Untill the stranger came.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What stranger.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Signior Bentivolio
Nay I know nothing by 'em, but he has
A most prevailing tongue upon a gentle-woman.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My feares! have I advanc'd him to supplant me?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Bentivolio so gracious with the Duke?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Hee's courted next Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Tis for her
We may imagine the Duke graces him.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: Oh there is noe such instrument, beleeve it
As a Court-Lady to advance a gentleman,
Or any masculine busines, they are Sticklers

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more. Signior Bentivolio.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Where's Horatio.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: He was afraid you might kill one another,
And so hee's gon to hang himselfe.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Better all
Thy generation were executed, but I must to my charge

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Your highnes powers
Such infinite graces on me I shall want
Life to expresse my pious duties, though
Time should assure me ages.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thanke Ardelia,
Or if you would expresse your gratitude
To me.
employ your wit, and tongue, to gaine
That Lady to our close embrace, you have
A powerfull language, be it your first service
We doe not place this confidence on all.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You meane Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That faire one, Strozzi.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: Well Signior Bentivolio, my quondam
Friend, and fellow traveller, you owe
To me a part of your Court exaltation,
And least you should forget, as few great men
Are guilty of good memories, I meane
To pay my selfe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I must not appeare troubled.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I congratulate your favor with the Duke,
And thinke it, not the least of my owne happines.
That I was a poore instrument—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You honour'd me,
And shall command my services: how sped
My friend Horatio?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: He gave me thankes
I ha fitted him, you mist excellent sport.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I shall have time to enquire, and thanke you for
The Storie, you know how to excuse me friend,
If some engagements force me hence?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Why so.
He has the tricke already, full of busines,
Court agitations, he is yet scarce warme,
How will he use us when his pride boyles over?
A nod will be a grace, while we stand bare,
And thanke him for the rufling of his countenance,
And discomposing his Court face, that's bound
Upon some State affaires, tis very well.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Give him accesse, thou hast shew'd diligence,
And trust me to reward it.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Tis my duty sir.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I have some intelligence wil be worth your hearing too.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Speake Signior Valerio.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: Doe you know the gentleman
Whom you have grac'd so lately.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Signior Bentivolio.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: That's his name, but doe you know his nature?
Or his busines in these parts.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Prethee instruct me.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: You doe but warme a Serpent in your bosome,
In short he loves your Mistres.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ho's?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: More is contracted,
And they both practise cunning, I ha search'd
His heart— your eare—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The Duke seemes moov'd,

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Most strangely!

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Expect a while.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Humbly your graces pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: Your highnes shall not wast a passion,
I am of counsell with his thoughts, and will
Present him ripe to your just anger, trust me
To manage things a while.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Honest Valerio.
Val. Keepe your face smooth, least he interpret Sir,
I ha' betraid him, ere his head be readie
For the execution, it were necessary
I should examine her pulse too.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Ardelia's?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ile creepe into her soule to bring you all
The best intelligence.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Precious Ualerio!
Endeare me by this service, thou hast my heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My dutie shall preserve it.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Strozzi.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: This is the gentleman, an't please
Your highnesse, can discover most strange things.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: To your private eare.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Ardelia? my best health,
Deare as my soule, I cannot be long absent.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So, how shall I begin now?
Madam, I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: To me
Noble Valerio, be confident
For your owne worth, if any power of mine
Can serve your wish, you shall not finde me slow
To exercise it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, tis in your power.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Presume tis finishd then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In your free power,
Without the Duke, or other to confirme it.
Y'are flesh, and blood.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: What meane you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No other than I say, nor wish it other,
A woman is a partner in the frailty
Of humane nature, and knowes how to excuse
The errors of our blood, and yet you shall
Have cause to give me thanks, when you consider
My sence, and your owne state, whatdee' thinke
Of me?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For what you please to call it,
My persons not contemptible, though I be
No Duke, I can behave my selfe to please
Where I am accepted.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Whats your purpose Signior?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You cannot sure be ignorant of my meaning,
Theres not a girle of seaven yeares old, but will
Expound it readily, here we sucke this language
And our milke together, I could have us'd
More circumstance, have prais'd you into folly,
And when I had put out both your eies with Metaphors,
Lead you to my desires, and to your pillow:
But 'twas about, I could have said I lov'd you,
Lookd sad, and squeez'd my eies, have sigh'd perhaps,
And sworne my selfe quite over breath, that I
Thought you a Saint, and my heart suffer'd more
Than the ten persecutions; hang't, time's precious,
I take the neerest way, which your discretion
Will like me for, yet I can love you too,
And would for thy embrace forget asmuch
Goodnesse, and tempt as many mischiefes as,
Another man, I hope you understand me.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I am lost, and see a blacke conspiracie.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You shall see me naked. I ha' no conspiracies,
Carrie no private engines more then nature
Arm'd me withall, be wise and doe not tremble.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How dare you be thus insolent? though my per-son
Move you to no regard, you shall finde one
Will teach you manners.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You would meane the Duke now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Has that name no more reverence owing to it?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Yes, I desire no better judge, he'l heare
Us both, and equally determine all;
Let's to his highnesse streight.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What meanes this rudenesse?

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: You are the Dukes game-royall, or els should
Be the mistris of his thoughts, whose nod does make
Us tremble, and in time may be the Dutchesse,
Unles your sweete heart Bentivolio
Snap you before him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What fine netts you walke in,
You are noe, Jugler, there has past noe contract
Betwixt you, and the gallant, no? and while,
The honest easie Duke, whose spirit raise not,
Doates on that face, humbled beneath a subject,
You have noe private meetings, change no kisses,
Nor hot carreers, alas hee's but a Stranger
Whom you respect but for the bare resemblance
Of a dead brother, there's noe flame in you
But what lights you to charity; I wast breath,
The Duke is yet that tame thing, you ha left him,
His soule in a dreame, let not your folly,
And peevish opposition to receive
Me to your armes, wake him into a tempest,
The lightning cannot moove more nimbly, then
His rage to both your deaths, your Ganimede
Will find the Dukes revenge in his hot blood,
When his heart weeping the last drope shall have
Noe pity waite upon 'em, that durst feed
The rivall to a Prince, though common men
For want of power, and courage to revenge
Neglect their shame, wild Princes that know all things,
Beneath their feete but heaven, obey noe fate,
And but to be reveng'd will hazard that.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Not so Madam,
You shall lead destiny in cords of Silke,
And it shall follow tame, and to your pleasure,
The Duke knowes nothing yet, you shall seale up
My lip to eternall silence of your love,
If I may but injoy you, you shall rule
With the same sway his bosome, and possesse
Your wealth in Bentivolio too, I'me but
A friend or rather servant, that shall be
Proud of your smile, and now, and then admitted
To kisse you when the Curtaines drawne, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Who plac'd me on this precipice? sir, heare me,
Tis vaine to aske how you deriv'd the knowledge
Of what I thought conceal'd, you are a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: That does appeare by my desires.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Have yet some mercy
On a distressed maid.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Maid? thanke you for that, I wo'd you were
Indeed, virginity is wiser then
Men take it for, and therefore we distinguish,
There is one virginity in the wedge, or bullion
As we may say, and this we call lunor maiden-head,
And there's another in the coine, the gold
Is not lesse gold for the impression,
Your maiden-head is currant in this sence.
And in this maiden-sence you may give Milke.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: By all the goodnes that I wish were in you,
Not Bentivolio, whom you thinke I most
Affect, hath more of me then virgin knowledge,
Nor hath the Duke with all his flatteries
Wrong'd my first State, although I must confesse
